statement.p:
Let A \and B be sets.
A \subseteq B \iff (x \in A) \to (x \in B)
x \in A \cup B \iff x \in A \lor x \in B
x \in A \cap B \iff x \in A \land x \in B
x \in A \setminus B \iff x \in A \land x \not\in B
A = B if and only if A \subseteq B and B \subseteq A.

Prove that if S is any set:
\emptyset \subseteq S
S \subseteq S

li.p: The logical statement we're trying to prove is (x \in \emptyset) \to (x \in S)

Assume that x \in \emptyset. This is false, since nothing is in the empty set. That means that the conditional statement (x \in \emptyset) \to (x\in S) is vacuously true, since the conditional F \to p is always true. Thus \emptyset \subseteq S.
The logical statement we're trying to prove is (x \in S) \to (x\in S)
Assume that x \in S. Then x \in S is trivially true. Thus S \subseteq S.

statement.p:
Prove the following identities:
A \cup \emptyset = A
A \subseteq (A \cup B)
A \cap (A \cup B) = A
\overline{A \cup B} = \overline{A} \cap \overline{B}

solution.p:
We'll prove the first via an iff argument:
x\in A \cup \emptyset \amp \iff x \in A \lor x\in \emptyset \amp \iff x\in A \lor F \amp \iff x\in A
thus A \cup \emptyset = A.

statement.p:
Let A, B, \and C be sets. Prove the following identities:
A \cup (B \cup C) = (A \cup B) \cup C
\overline{\overline{A}} = A
A \cup (A \cap B) = A
A \cup (B \cap C) = (A \cup B) \cap (A \cup C)
\overline{A \cap B} = \overline{A} \cup \overline{B}
A \subseteq B if and only if \overline{B} \subseteq \overline{A}
